4845.meaning_1: name of a town of the Mallas; Anupiya
4845.comments: Proper noun referring to a specific town in the land of the Mallas where the Buddha stayed.

23126.meaning_1: a naked ascetic of the Korakha clan; a naked ascetic named Korakha
23126.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence, korakhattiya refers to a naked ascetic (acela) named Korakha who is questioned about his knowledge of his own destiny after death.
23126.example_1: kālaṅkatañca naṃ bīraṇatthambake susāne chaḍḍessanti. ākaṅkhamāno ca tvaṃ, sunakkhatta, acelaṃ korakkhattiyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā puccheyyāsi, jānāsi, āvuso korakkhattiya [acela korakhattiya], attano gatinti? ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, sunakkhatta, vijjati yaṃ te acelo korakkhattiyo byākarissati, jānāmi, āvuso sunakkhatta, attano gatiṃ, kālakañcikā nāma asurā sabbanihīno asurakāyo, tatrāmhi upapannoti.

22797.meaning_1: corpse; carcass; dead body; disgusting thing
22797.comments: In the contextual sentence, kūṇapāni refers to discarded carcasses or foul objects thrown in the forest, aligning with both meanings of corpse and disgusting thing.
22797.example_1:
bhutvāna bheke [bhiṅge] khalamūsikāyo,
kaṭasīsu khittāni ca koṇapāni [kūṇapāni],
mahāvane suññavane vivaḍḍho,
amaññi kotthu migarājāhamasmi.

57357.COMMENTS: In the contextual sentence from DN24, sañjitā appears in a list of epithets of Brahmā, emphasizing his role as creator of beings. The form sajjitā is a variant spelling.
57357.example_1: 39. tatrāvuso, yo so satto paṭhamaṃ upapanno, tassa evaṃ hoti, ahamasmi brahmā mahābrahmā abhibhū anabhibhūto aññadatthudaso vasavattī issaro kattā nimmātā seṭṭho sajitā [sañjitā, sajjitā] vasī pitā bhūtabhabyānaṃ, mayā ime sattā nimmitā. taṃ kissa hetu?

25230.comments: Used figuratively in the contextual sentence to suggest treating the Buddha as an outcast or someone easily dismissed or defeated, like a defective cow sent to the periphery.
25230.sutta_1: Ayaṁ kho so, bhante, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho idhānuppatto, aparisāvacaraṁ pana naṁ karotha, gokāṇaṁ pariyantacāriniṁ karotha, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādetha, tucchakumbhīva naṁ orodhethā”ti.
25230.example_1: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a one-eyed cow? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”

52837.comment: In the given context, "mucchati" means becoming infatuated or negligent due to a certain practice or condition.
52837.sutta_1: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati, so tena tapasā majjati mucchati pamādamāpajjati.
52837.example_1: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification. They become indulgent and infatuated and fall into negligence on account of that.

55744.meaning_1: out of a desire for gain, honour and fame; for the purpose of possessions, respect and popularity
55744.comment: The compound "lābhasakkārasiloka" is a dvanda compound, and "nikantihetu" is a chaṭṭhī tappurisa compound.
55744.sutta_1: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī tapaṁ samādiyati lābhasakkārasilokanikantihetu:
55744.example_1: Furthermore, a mortifier undertakes a practice of mortification out of longing for possessions, honor, and popularity, thinking,

48188.meaning_1: with an excessive lifestyle; living in luxury
48188.comment: In the given context, "bahulājīvo" describes someone who lives luxuriously or excessively.
48188.example_1: 61. puna caparaṃ, nigrodha, tapassī aññataraṃ samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā apasādetā [apasāretā] hoti, kiṃ panāyaṃ sambahulājīvo [bahulājīvo] sabbaṃ saṃbhakkheti. seyyathidaṃ, mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ, asanivicakkaṃ dantakūṭaṃ, samaṇappavādenāti … ayampi kho, nigrodha, tapassino upakkileso hoti.

9426.comment: The word "asanivicakka" is used to describe something that is "crunched together like the thunder of a tooth-hammer". It is likely a metaphorical or descriptive term.
9426.sutta_1: Seyyathidaṁ—mūlabījaṁ khandhabījaṁ phaḷubījaṁ aggabījaṁ bījabījameva pañcamaṁ, asanivicakkaṁ dantakūṭaṁ, samaṇappavādenā’ti …pe…
9426.example_1: plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth—is crunched together like the thunder of a tooth-hammer!’

2862.comment: The word "adassayamāna" is used to describe someone sneaking about among families, indicating the act of hiding or not showing oneself.
2862.sutta_1: Puna caparaṁ, nigrodha, tapassī attānaṁ adassayamāno kulesu carati:
2862.example_1: Furthermore, a mortifier sneaks about among families, thinking,

23492.comment: The word khamamāna is used to describe something or someone that is enduring or tolerating, as seen in the contextual sentence: "Khamamānaṁ āha: ‘nakkhamatī’ti." This indicates that khamamāna is related to the act of enduring or being patient.
23492.example_1: Or they say it isn’t, even though it is.

64306.comment: The Sumāgadhā is a river near Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
64306.sutta_1: Atha kho bhagavā gijjhakūṭā pabbatā orohitvā yena sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā sumāgadhāya tīre moranivāpe abbhokāse caṅkami.
64306.example_1: Then the Buddha descended from Vulture’s Peak Mountain and went to the peacocks’ feeding ground on the bank of the Sumāgadhā, where he walked mindfully in the open air.

62485.meaning_1: reached the heart; attained the essence
62485.comment: In the given context, "sārappattā" implies that the practice or the path has reached its core or essence, signifying a deep level of attainment or understanding.
62485.sutta_1: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante tapojigucchā parisuddhā hoti no aparisuddhā, aggappattā ca sārappattā cā”ti.
62485.example_1: “Clearly, sir, it is purified. It has reached the peak and the pith.”

2197.meaning_lit: causes to fall all the way
2197.comment: The contextual sentence from DN25 illustrates the meaning of "atipātayati" as getting others to kill, highlighting its causative nature.
2197.sutta_1: Idha, nigrodha, tapassī na pāṇaṁ atipāteti, na pāṇaṁ atipātayati, na pāṇamatipātayato samanuñño hoti.
2197.example_1: It’s when a mortifier doesn’t kill living creatures, doesn’t get others to kill, and doesn’t approve of killing.

49233.meaning_1: causes to speak; makes say; causes to tell
49233.comment: In the given contextual sentence, "bhaṇāpeti" is used in the context of not getting others to lie, highlighting its causative nature related to speaking or telling.
49233.sutta_1: Na musā bhaṇati, na musā bhaṇāpeti, na musā bhaṇato samanuñño hoti.
49233.example_1: They don’t lie, get others to lie, or approve of lying.

49226.comment: In the given context, "musā bhaṇato" means "lied" or "told lies".
49226.sutta_1: ‘karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato socayato, socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātāpayato, adinnaṁ ādiyato, sandhiṁ chindato, nillopaṁ harato, ekāgārikaṁ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṁ gacchato, musā bhaṇato, karoto na karīyati pāpaṁ. Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṁ maṁsakhalaṁ ekaṁ maṁsapuñjaṁ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṁ pāpaṁ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
49226.example_1: ‘Great king, the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

29245.comments: The word "tacappattā" means having reached the inner bark, indicating a stage of development or growth.
29245.example_1: Rather, it has only reached the bark.”

39747.comment: The word pajjhāyana is used in the context of DN25 to describe the brooding or sullenness of Nigrodha.

13705.meaning_1: arrived here; reached here; come here
13705.comments: The contextual sentence shows the word is used to describe the Buddha as having arrived or come to a particular place.
13705.sutta_1: Ayaṁ kho so, bhante, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho idhānuppatto, aparisāvacaraṁ pana naṁ karotha, gokāṇaṁ pariyantacāriniṁ karotha, ekapañheneva naṁ saṁsādetha, tucchakumbhīva naṁ orodhethā”ti.
13705.example_1: Now the Blessed One, perfected and fully awakened, has arrived here. Why don’t you send him out of the assembly to the periphery like a one-eyed cow? Why don’t you sink him with just one question? Why don’t you roll him over and wrap him up like a hollow pot?”

53666.meaning_lit: like a fool; like a confused person
53666.comment: The word "yathāmūḷhena" is used to describe the manner in which someone spoke, indicating they did so foolishly or without proper understanding.
53666.sutta_1: “Saccaṁ, bhante, bhāsitā me esā vācā, yathābālena yathāmūḷhena yathāakusalenā”ti.
53666.example_1: “It’s true, sir, those are my words. It was foolish, stupid, and unskillful of me.”

61585.comment: In the given context, saṃgamma means "having come together" or "having met", indicating the action of the arahanto sammāsambuddhā engaging in various types of discussions.
61585.example_1: taṃ kiṃ maññasi, nigrodha. kinti te sutaṃ paribbājakānaṃ vuḍḍhānaṃ mahallakānaṃ ācariyapācariyānaṃ bhāsamānānaṃ, ye te ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, evaṃ su te bhagavanto saṃgamma samāgamma unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā anekavihitaṃ tiracchānakathaṃ anuyuttā viharanti. seyyathidaṃ, rājakathaṃ corakathaṃ … itibhavābhavakathaṃ iti vā.

57943.meaning_1: fearful; full of anxiety; anxious; uneasy
57943.comment: In the given context, sadarā dhammā refers to "fearful" or "anxious" mental states.
57943.example_1: iti khvāhaṃ, nigrodha, neva antevāsikamyatā evaṃ vadāmi, napi uddesā cāvetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ājīvā cāvetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā [napi ye kho dhammā, napi ye te dhammā, napi ye ca vo dhammā] akusalā akusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tesu patiṭṭhāpetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi, napi ye vo dhammā [napi ye kho dhammā, napi ye te dhammā, napi ye ca vo dhammā] kusalā kusalasaṅkhātā sācariyakānaṃ, tehi vivecetukāmo evaṃ vadāmi. santi ca kho, nigrodha, akusalā dhammā appahīnā saṃkilesikā ponobbhavikā [ponobhavikā] sadarā [saddarā, sadarathā] dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā, yesāhaṃ pahānāya dhammaṃ desemi. yathāpaṭipannānaṃ vo saṃkilesikā dhammā pahīyissanti, vodānīyā dhammā abhivaḍḍhissanti, paññāpāripūriṃ vepullattañca diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissathāti.

25697.comment: The Cakkavattisutta is the 26th sutta of the Dīgha Nikāya.

32213.comment: The word "daḷhanemi" refers to a mythological king in Buddhist literature, as seen in the contextual sentence from DN 26.2.1.
32213.sutta_1: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi nāma ahosi cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā cāturanto vijitāvī janapadatthāvariyappatto sattaratanasamannāgato.
32213.example_1: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a king named Daḷhanemi who was a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extended to all four sides, he achieved stability in the country, and he possessed the seven treasures.

18958.meaning_1: to withdraw; to retreat; to move back
18958.comment: The verb "osakkati" is used in the context of something slipping or moving back, as seen in the sentence from DN 26 where the divine wheel-treasure of a wheel-turning monarch moves back from its place, indicating the monarch does not have long to live.
18958.sutta_1: yassa rañño cakkavattissa dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ osakkati ṭhānā cavati, na dāni tena raññā ciraṁ jīvitabbaṁ hotīti.
18958.example_1: when this happens to a wheel-turning monarch, he does not have long to live.

59379.meaning_1: having thoroughly advised; having instructed well
59379.comment: The word "samanusāsitvā" is used in the context of King Daḷhanemi instructing his crown prince in kingship before renouncing his throne.
59379.sutta_1: Atha kho, bhikkhave, rājā daḷhanemi jeṭṭhaputtaṁ kumāraṁ sādhukaṁ rajje samanusāsitvā kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbaji.
59379.example_1: And so, after carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Daḷhanemi shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

57824.meaning_1: ordained for seven days; renounced for a week
57824.comments: The term "sattāhapabbajita" refers to someone who has been ordained for seven days, indicating a recent or temporary renunciation.
57824.sutta_1: Sattāhapabbajite kho pana, bhikkhave, rājisimhi dibbaṁ cakkaratanaṁ antaradhāyi.
57824.example_1: Seven days later the heavenly wheel-treasure vanished.

63277.meaning_1: who has washed their head; who has bathed their head
63277.comment: The compound "sīsanhāta" is used to describe someone who has washed or bathed their head, likely in the context of preparing for a significant event or observance, such as the uposatha day mentioned in the contextual sentence from DN26.
63277.example_1: iṅgha tvaṃ, tāta, ariye cakkavattivatte vattāhi. ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ vijjati, yaṃ te ariye cakkavattivatte vattamānassa tadahuposathe pannarase sīsaṃnhātassa [sīsaṃ nahātassa, sīsanhātassa] uposathikassa uparipāsādavaragatassa dibbaṃ cakkaratanaṃ pātubhavissati sahassāraṃ sanemikaṃ sanābhikaṃ sabbākāraparipūranti.

34745.comment: In the contextual sentence, this term describes a ruler who takes the Dhamma as their guiding principle and standard.
34745.sutta_1: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
34745.example_1: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

34663.comment: In the contextual sentence, dhammaketu is used metaphorically to describe someone who upholds the Dhamma as their guiding principle or standard, like a banner leading an army.
34663.sutta_1: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
34663.example_1: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

34940.comment: In the contextual sentence, this term is used to describe a ruler who governs with Dhamma as their supreme authority, providing just protection for all beings.
34940.sutta_1: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
34940.example_1: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

38731.meaning_1: people of town and country; urban and rural inhabitants
38731.comment: The compound refers collectively to urban (negama) and rural (jānapada) populations, indicating a comprehensive societal scope in the context of governance and protection.
38731.sutta_1: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
38731.example_1: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

52535.comment: The compound migapakkhī is a dvanda (coordinative) compound combining "miga" (beasts) and "pakkhī" (birds), referring collectively to animals and birds as seen in the contextual sentence where it appears in a list of beings to be protected.
52535.sutta_1: ‘Tena hi tvaṁ, tāta, dhammaṁyeva nissāya dhammaṁ sakkaronto dhammaṁ garuṁ karonto dhammaṁ mānento dhammaṁ pūjento dhammaṁ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṁ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidahassu antojanasmiṁ balakāyasmiṁ khattiyesu anuyantesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu negamajānapadesu samaṇabrāhmaṇesu migapakkhīsu.
52535.example_1: ‘Well then, my dear, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as your flag, banner, and authority—provide just protection and security for your court, troops, aristocrats, vassals, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.
